Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Efficient Statistical Computing on Riemannian Manifolds with Applications to Medical Imaging and Computer Vision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops efficient incremental algorithms are proposed for computing averages and other statistical quantities of interest from pools of data incrementally acquired. Many existing data acquisition and processing methods have reached a level of sophistication so as to be able to acquire and/or synthesize data that reside in curved spaces such as spheres, hyperboloids etc. As such data have become ubiquitous in many Science and Engineering fields, need for efficient statistical analysis of these data has emerged as an area of significant importance. Further, in this era of massive and continuous streaming data, samples of data are acquired sequentially over time. Hence, from an applications and computational efficiency perspective, the desired averaging algorithm ought to be amenable to incremental updates to accommodate the newly acquired data over time. The developed algorithms can be applied different applications, such as face recognition from videos, action recognition, trajectory averaging and clustering from videos, image and video restoration, pattern clustering and classification, etc. In the context of diagnostic medical imaging, methods developed in this project can be used to automatically discriminate between various disease classes, such as Parkinson's and Essential Tremor which are distinct types of movement disorders.

This research investigates a general framework for recursive computation of the intrinsic mean and the principal geodesic analysis on several commonly encountered manifolds such as the manifold of symmetric positive definite matrices, the Grassmann, the Stiefel manifolds, the hypersphere, the manifold of special orthogonal matrices, and several others. The research team applies the developed recursive framework of computing statistics from manifold-valued data to several tasks namely, atlas computation from diffusion MRI in Medical Imaging, inter-class discrimination between sub-types of a neuro-degenerative disorder using diffusion MRI, face and action recognition, image and shape retrieval in Computer Vision applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project was to develop efficient algorithms to compute statistics specifically population mean and variance from data that reside in curved spaces such as a sphere (e.g., earth) and many other curved spaces commonly encountered in numerous Engineering and Science applications.  During the course of the project, computationally efficient algorithms were developed for the aforementioned tasks and applied to a variety of applications. Some of these applications included estimation of the population mean as the representative of a group of normal human brain diffusion magnetic resonancce images (dMRI). The purpose here was to use this mean as a reference to compare patient dMRIs and assess the amount of change in the patient brain caused by the disease process. Further, also identify the location in the brain where this change is statistically significant.  dMRI is a relatively nascent  diagnostic imaging technique that allows one to non-invasively probe the neural connectivity patterns in the central nervous system. The tools developed in this project facilitate the inference of the neural connectivity patterns and assess the changes in them caused by disease process. The specific brain disease investigated during the course of this project was Parkinson Disease. We were able to assess the changes and localize them in the dMRI brain scans using the tools developed during the course of this project. Tools were also developed for classification of movement disorders using human brain dMRI data. Further, we also developed tools to perform longitudinal data analysis which facilitate tracking of the disease process over time. Our algorithm for this type of data analysis is agnostic to the number of data samples over time i.e., allows for unequal number of observations over time between subjects, which is quite common in clinical studies for a variety of reasons.

In the context of Computer Vision applications, we applied our methods to classification problems such as action and object recognition; data dimensionality reduction when data are high dimensional and reside in curved spaces. In all the work performed in this project the key ingradient was to exploit the geometry of the data space in designing algorithms, which made the algorithms unique in the chosen problem domains. Another key ingradient of the research was the development of recursive algorithms for computing the statistics from the given population. This feature allowed us to naturally tackle streaming data which is very commonly encountered in internet based applications such as movie streaming for entertaininment, astronomy, journalism (news) etc. We developed efficient methods to compress such data online i.e., as data becomes available without the need to store the large amounts of data and then compress it.

The research methods developed here are  Ÿtransformative because, automated assessment of changes caused in the human brain by neuronal disorders such as the Parkinson disease as well as classification between various movement disorders through efficient Medical Image Analysis  is of high significance to diagnostic Neuroimaging community and the general population of the nation and world. From a Computer Vision perspective, the research results disseminated to the community via publications reported in the final report are significant in the sense that the reported efficient online algorithm for linear and nonlinear dimensionality reduction (data compression) applicable to streaming data is a unique and parameter free technique unlike existing methods in literature.
